sentences.sentence: After the servant left the room she sat down, unable to support herself.
She looked so miserably( 糟糕地 ) ill that it was impossible for Darcy to leave her.
He could not stop himself from saying, in the gentlest of tones( 语气 ),
“Let me call your maid( 女仆 ).
Is there nothing I could bring that would relieve you?
May I get you a glass of wine?
You seem very ill.”
“No, I thank you,” she replied, trying to recover herself.
“There is nothing the matter with me.
I am quite well.
I am only distressed( 痛苦的 ) by some dreadful( 可怕的 ) news which I have just received from Longbourn.”
She burst into tears as she referred to it, and for a few minutes could not speak another word.
At last she spoke again.
“I have just gotten a letter from Jane with dreadful( 可怕的 ) news.
I cannot hide it from anyone.
My younger sister has left all her friends( 朋友 ), and eloped( 私奔 ) with Mr. Wickham.
They have gone off together from Brighton.
You know him too well to have any doubt about the rest.
She has no money, no connections, and nothing that can persuade him to—she is lost forever.”
“I am very upset,” cried Darcy, “grieved( 伤心的 )—shocked.
But is it certain—absolutely( 完全地 ) certain?”
"Oh, yes! They left Brighton together on Sunday night, and were followed almost to London, but they have not yet been found.
They have certainly not gone to Scotland.”
“And what has been done to try and bring her back?”
“My father has gone to London, and Jane has written to beg for my uncle’s immediate assistance( 帮助 ).
We will leave, I hope, in half an hour.
But nothing can be done—I know very well that nothing can be done.
What can be done to persuade such a man? How can they even be found? I have not even the smallest hope.
It is in every way horrible( 可怕的 )!”
Darcy gave no answer.
He hardly seemed to hear her, and was walking up and down the room in deep thought.
Elizabeth soon observed this, and instantly understood it.
His love for her was shrinking( 消退 ).
Everything must shrink( 消退 ) under the threat( 威胁 ) of such a great disgrace( 耻辱 ).
She had never felt so honestly before that she could love him as she did now, when all her love would be for nothing.
Finally, Darcy responded.
“I am afraid that you have wanted me to leave for quite some time now.
In fact, I have no excuse for my long stay, except for my real, though useless concern.
This will, I fear, unfortunately mean that my sister will not be able to see you at Pemberley today.”
“Oh, yes. Please apologize for us to Miss Darcy.
Tell her that urgent( 紧急的 ) business calls us home immediately.
Conceal( 隐瞒 ) the unhappy truth for as long as it is possible, I know it cannot be for long.”
He immediately promised his secrecy, and again expressed how sorry he was for her distress( 不幸 ).
With only one serious, parting look, he went away.
As he left the room, Elizabeth felt how unlikely it was that they would ever see each other again.
“I have been thinking it over again, Elizabeth,” said her uncle, as they drove from the town;
“and it seems to me very unlikely that any young man should form such a design against a girl who was actually staying in with his colonel’s family.
What would be the effect on his career( 职业 )? The temptation( 诱惑 ) is not adequate( 足够的 ) to the risk!
Can you yourself, Lizzy, believe him capable( 能胜任的 ) of it?”
“Not, perhaps, of neglecting( 忽视 ) his own interest; but of every other neglect( 忽视 ) I can believe him capable( 能胜任的 ).
Why should they not go on to Scotland if he was really going to marry her?”
“Even if they are in London, they may feel that they could be more cheaply, though less quickly, married in London than in Scotland.”
“But why all this secrecy in that case?” asked Elizabeth.
“Wickham will never marry a woman without some money.
He cannot afford it.
And what claims has Lydia—what attraction has she beyond youth, health, and good humor that could make him, for her sake( 理由 ), give up every chance of benefiting himself by marrying well?”
“But can you think that Lydia is so lost to everything but love of him as to agree to live with him on any terms other than marriage?”
“It does seem, and it is most shocking indeed,” replied Elizabeth, with tears in her eyes,
“to doubt my sister’s sense of decency( 体面 ) and virtue( 贞操 ).
But she is very young: she has never been taught to think on serious subjects.
And we all know how charming( 迷人的 ) and captivating( 令人神魂颠倒的 ) Wickham can be.
We also know that he has neither integrity( 正直 ) nor honor, and that he is as false and deceitful( 虚伪的 ) as he is insinuating( 谄媚的 ).”
“And do you really know all this?” cried Mrs. Gardiner.
“I do indeed,” replied Elizabeth.
“I told you, the other day, of his infamous( 无耻的 ) behavior to Mr. Darcy.
And there are other circumstances( 事情 ) which I am not at liberty( 自由 )—well, let us just say that his lies about the whole Pemberley family are endless.”
“But does Lydia know nothing of this? How can she not know what you and Jane seem to understand so well?”
“Oh, yes!—that is the worst of all.
As the regiment( 团 ) was leaving soon, neither Jane nor I thought it necessary to make our knowledge public, since Wickham would soon be gone.”
They traveled as quickly as possible, and reached Longbourn by dinnertime( 晚餐时间 ) the next day.
It was comforting to consider that Jane could not have been worried by a long wait.
Elizabeth jumped out and hurried into the house, where Jane immediately met her.
Elizabeth affectionately( 亲切地 ) embraced( 拥抱 ) her, while tears filled the eyes of both.
She did not waste a moment before asking whether anything had been heard from Lydia or Wickham.
When they were all in the drawing-room, the questions which Elizabeth had already asked were of course repeated by the others.
They soon found that Jane had no news to give.
Mrs. Bennet’s reaction was exactly as could be expected, with tears and cries of regret, and complaints( 抱怨 ) about how badly everyone had treated her.
